qas.question: With whom did Von Neumann work on the Manhattan Project?

answers.text: J. Robert Oppenheimer and Edward Teller

qas.question: Post World War II, in what role did Von Neumann work?

answers.text: General Advisory Committee of the United States Atomic Energy Commission

qas.question: For what organizations was Von Neumann a consultant after World War II?

answers.text: United States Air Force, the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project, and the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

qas.question: What keys steps did Von Neumann work out that contributed to weapons of war?

answers.text: key steps in the nuclear physics involved in thermonuclear reactions and the hydrogen bomb

context: During World War II he worked on the Manhattan Project with <a0_0>J. Robert Oppenheimer and Edward Teller<a0_0/>, developing the mathematical models behind the explosive lenses used in the implosion-type nuclear weapon. After the war, he served on the <a1_0>General Advisory Committee of the United States Atomic Energy Commission<a1_0/>, and later as one of its commissioners. He was a consultant to a number of organizations, including the <a2_0>United States Air Force, the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project, and the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory<a2_0/>. Along with theoretical physicist Edward Teller, mathematician Stanislaw Ulam, and others, he worked out <a3_0>key steps in the nuclear physics involved in thermonuclear reactions and the hydrogen bomb<a3_0/>.
